ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was given much more freedom in my research and the ability to guide my own project but still had the help of my PI when I needed it. I also learned how to better write a lab notebook.
Knowledge of the hematopoetic system, FACs, stem cell handling, CFU assays
Stem cell biology, planarian biology, and a whole lot other molecular biology techniques
I learned all about C. elegant as a model organism. I also learned about brood size assays, hermaphroditic self fertilization, and a bit about epigenetic dynamics of autosomes and the X chromosome

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength: access to lab environment Weakness: mostly observational
I like being able to learn about the culture of a lab before deciding.
Maybe officially end before winter break

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This was a great rotation that had the perfect balance of independence and PI involvement.

Yes, because you have to know how a lab functions both techniques and interpersonally. I found that this rotation was too hands off, and did not increase my confidence in myself as a competent scientist.
